sect1.title: So you want to add a probe?
sect1.para: Are you really sure? Adding a probe involves writing C code, creating and designing database tables and queue result files, creating PHP pages, and PHP graphs, writing documentation and submitting these changes to CVS. It is a lot of work, how rewarding it may be.
In the following overview we'll show you how to add a probe. All man-pages, spec-files, documentation will be auto-generated if you follow instructions below.

sect1.title: Basic steps for adding a probe

sect2.title: Think carefully before you start
sect2.para: You should not think lightly of adding a probe. Think things over before you start. Isn't there a probe available you can use? Or maybe you can get away with extending an existing one? If not, perhaps you can copy and modify one?
If not, you're in for the rewarding process of adding a new probe. Go to the next step.

sect2.title: Pick a real good name
sect2.para: You should think of a real good descriptive name for your probe. It should describe exactly what it does. Leave room for future probes that do something similar, also think about future extension to the probe itself.. Don't be satisfied too soon. For the rest of this small tutorial, we'll assume you probe willed be called cputemp for monitoring the host CPU temperature.

sect2.title: Design the Database Layout
sect2.para: Take a close look at the database layout for existing probes. Each probe at least consists of the following tables:

listitem.para: A definition table (of course). This contains the probe id, target, last status, when to turn yellow or red
Table for raw output, all results are kept here
A history table to keep all status changes

sect2.para: Design these tables in uw_cputemp.mysql. You will copy this file in the next section.
Also a probe needs to enter its status into pr_status, and its history into pr_history and you should add code for this in the uw_process part..

sect2.title: Write the code
sect2.para: Create a new directory named uw_cputemp, copy all files in templates/probe to it. Look into those files, do a search and replace all occurrences of template with cputemp. Go one directory up, edit configure.in. Add a line uw_cputemp/Makefile to the AC_CONFIG_FILES section. Add uw_cputemp to the PROGNAMES variable in Makefile.am. Run:

Now start coding in uw_cputemp/run.c, specifically in the function run(). You should have enough examples in the other probes. Basically the probe should read a list of probedefinitions from a database, execute all probes, and writes the results into a spoolfile. There are utility functions for doing this in libupwatch.

important.para: Test your code thoroughly for memory leaks and error conditions.

sect2.title: Write the uw_process extension
sect2.para: The output of your probe is processed by uw_process. You should add a new source file called process_cputemp.c, that reads the probe results and writes them to the database tables. Be careful for the logic in this part. Add an entry in the struct _probe_proc array in uw_process/run.c, and a extern int process_cputemp(char *spec, GString *remark); just above it.

listitem.para: Copy all *.php files from templates/php-cms to the en/database directory. Rename every *template* file to *cputemp*.
Copy the pr_template_def.rec file to /home/cms/home/cms/www/php/cms. Do the usual replace, and take care this def file reflects the layout of pr_cputemp_def table in the database.
Go to www/php/cms/custforms.php. Find the line which says START OF PROBES. Add an entry to the $f_probes array.
Copy a section of another probe. Adapt as needed.

important.para: Create an empty record in the database with id = 1i

sect2.title: Write documentation
sect2.para: Note that every probe is documented briefly in the cmd_options.def file. You should also document the probe in this manual. Personally I use KDE's Kate with the XML plugin. Go the the doc directory. Copy template-specs.xml to cputemp-specs.xml. Add a line to probesspecs.xml, and an ENTITY line at the top of upwatch.xml. Add cputemp-specs.xml to the XMLFILES line in Makefile.am. Rerun ./autogen.sh, ./configure in the top directory. Run make in the doc directory.
